body: I recommend doing this in iptables (i.e. at the point where you direct traffic into mitmproxy, instead of in mitmproxy itself). You can easily ignore specific IP-ranges.
I want that feature too. I often have to close mitmproxy and open Fiddler or Charles proxy when I'm inspecting some apps that use Apple in-app purchases.

Another use case that should be considered:
My question now is how can I pass HTTPS traffic through the proxy an leave the original certs intact? At this point I am uninterested in intercepting encrypted traffic.
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/mitmproxy/zBFpAqg19hI

I need this too!

I use mitmproxy to debug my mobile APP. In the app, Login , Logout use HTTPS , other request use HTTP . In most situation, I just debug the http request. But before that , I must login the APP in the TEST Server .  

I try fiddler , it can use "http connect tunnel " handle this situation , what should I do with mitmproxy ?

Hey all,

just to keep you updated, support for SSL pass-through has been added to the master branch over the last few weeks and will be part of the next major release. We'll expose a command line switch to filter by hostname, ip and port. If you think that this is not sufficient for your usecase, please let me know.

Testing still involves [mitmproxy from git master](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/50#issuecomment-34479477) and manually [editing the source code](https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/blob/master/libmproxy/proxy.py#L358) right now. As soon as we have the command line switch exposed and documentation added, we'll post a short update here.

Cheers,
Max
A great news, it is. Thanks mhils
Max, it would be great if you make possible to include regex or wildcards. Most of the time I want to just ignore everything that is a subdomain of apple.com

issue.title: Add option to skip processing some responses

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.body:
Mitmproxy processes all requests and parses all responses, sending them to the client when the response is complete. For big  responses (e.g. streaming movies) this introduces unnecessary delays and/or timeouts.

I'd like to be able (in a script request method) to mark some requests so as the responses to them will be forwarded straight to client without parsing. They might even be not stored in the dump file.

body:
Hi all,

I just landed an initial version of the passthrough/ignore mode on master. 

```
> mitmproxy -h

optional arguments:
  [...]
  -I HOST, --ignore HOST
                        Ignore host and forward all traffic without processing
                        it. In transparent mode, it is recommended to use an
                        IP address (range), not the hostname. In regular mode,
                        only SSL traffic is ignored and the hostname should be
                        used. The supplied value is interpreted as a regular
                        expression and matched on the ip or the hostname. Can
                        be passed multiple times.
  [...]
```

One can now specify multiple hosts/ips to ignore, e.g. `mitmproxy -I apple\.com -I 17\.172\.224\.\d+`. The interface is fairly raw and close to the core, but I think anyone who's interested in such functionality will get it right with some fiddling. We'll add some more verbose documentation later on.

If anyone wants to try this out, please install mitmproxy from master (https://gist.github.com/mhils/9315651) and let me know how it works for you. I'd love to have some feedback on this before the next release! :-)

Thanks!
Max

Hi @timesking,

thanks for trying it out! It looks like you still have an old mitmproxy release in your python path, which you need to remove first. `python -c "from libmproxy import version; print version.VERSION"` should return 0.11.

Cheers,
Max

You are right, there is a lib in /usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages,
introduced by brew install mitmproxy.

BTW, Can I pass *.apple.com in -I?

> https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy/issues/175#issuecomment-51713642.

`-I` accepts a regular expression, which is matched on the hostname. `*.apple.com` is not a vaild regex, but `.*\.apple\.com$` works fine.

Cheers,
Max

Hi @Gotmymoney,

Really difficult to say where your pip error comes from. As a simple workaround, I'd recommend 

```
git clone https://github.com/mitmproxy/netlib.git
git clone https://github.com/mitmproxy/mitmproxy.git
cd netlib
pip install -e .
cd ../mitmproxy
pip install -e .
```

Please let me know whether that works for you! :-)

Picking the right regex obviously depends on your target. If you run `mitmproxy -v` and open the event log, you'll see `serverconnect` messages, which display the `host:port` string on which mitmproxy will filter. If your ignore pattern matches, you'll see a message in the log:

```
127.0.0.1:56995: serverconnect
  -> securemetrics.apple.com:443
127.0.0.1:56995: Ignore host: securemetrics.apple.com:443
```

A few examples:

Running mitmproxy in regular mode, the very lazy approach is 
`--ignore apple.com`, 
which ignore HTTP and HTTPS traffic for foo.apple.com, apple.com and even appletcom.org (. matches everything in regexes).
To only intercept HTTPS traffic, one could use
`--ignore apple.com:443`.
If you coincidentally want to connect to appletcom.org, the correct version would leave that out by escaping the dot:
`--ignore apple\.com:443`.
Now let's say you don't want to match the subdomains (not even www.):
`--ignore ^apple\.com:443`
etc. I think you should get the idea. That being said, the story is a little bit different in transparent mode - we don't have qualified hostnames here, only IPs:
`--ignore 17\.178\.96\.59:443`

Cheers,
Max

Thanks Max that work but now I can't get any traffic to flow it seems like the binding port information is different now. If I recall it use to display *:8080 now it reads 0.0.0.0:8080?

Adam

Hi @Gotmymoney,

0.0.0.0 binds to all interfaces, which is equivalent to *:8080. The difference in the UI has been an oversight and is fixed.
Regarding your problem: If you open the event log (`e`), you should be able to see `clientconnect` messages. If there are none, mitmproxy does not even receive a TCP connection. If you can observe clientconnect messages, try starting mitmproxy with `-v` and see whether there's anything meaningful in the log.

Cheers,
Max

Max,

Seemingly no matter what I do I can't seem to get any activity, the event log is quite, no clientconnect messages, etc. I have one client that is pointing its gateway setting to the mitmproxy it can ping the server and it use to connect prior to the upgrade. Any thoughts on the direction I should pursue.

Update, I have Putty installed on the client I can get some activity (errors) if I point at the IP of the server and port 8080..

On the client if I change the gateway back to the router, and start Mitmproxy not using transparent mode, and use the proxy settings in IE to point to SERVERIP:8080 everything seems to be OK.

Perhaps I should state this is the startup options I am using. I'd like the gateway of the client to be the only setting that I need to change (this is how I had it pre upgrade.)

mitmproxy -T -e -w "/Users/InnCashAlpha/desktop/Inncash Alpha Data/Logs/test --host

Does this have something to do with the routing perhaps and my use of transparent mode?
After upgrading would I need to redo "http://mitmproxy.org/doc/transparent/linux.html"  

Adam

Hi @Gotmymoney,

if I interpret this correctly, you're using mitmproxy in transparent mode. Does it work if you explicitly configure the proxy?
If that works, I'd suspect that ICMP Redirects are to blame here.

Cheers,
Max
